reviews.review_text: Very nice combination of Terraria and Lemmings. I definitely recommend, it's very casual, relaxing and enjoyable game with nice graphics, sounds and music.  Cons: - AI need some work, the way how AI select which dwarf do what is crappy, very annoying thing is to order dwarves to attack enemy, seems AI just remember the destination and until dwarves reach it, they ignore anything (aka other enemies on the way, or even that enemy if he moves, dwarves just keep running ><); - Some things are not easy to discover and they definitely needs to be in tutorial with a good explanation: deconstructing, farm + trap, comfort level, professions... - AI basic control of dwarves is not the best one, it would be much better to select dwarf and give him an order (or even set of orders), portal spell is a good way to set priority (because dwarves always choose the job close to stock and portal 'move' that point to stock in reachability). - Some predefinition are wrong or missing clear hints: level at which tree grows, at which snow falls, at which anything grows in cave. Digging one tile lower and suggenly you have no more resource (as wood or grown food) to replenish. E.g. different earth color placed by player could indicate that. - Grow rate is broken and annoying: tree may keep instantly grow at place where previous one was chopped, preventing that peace from digging, there must be a delay at given tile after removing resource from it, will it be a tree, bush, mushroom, crystal, etc. - Teleport spell should cost 1 mana and last longer, this is the only right way in the game to travel. On large map it become very annoying to move dwarves back/forth (it take too long to travel), elevator is bugged, train is not reliable and required investments (inculuding time), which not worth it. - Even after finishing game I have NO CLUE how many resources can one dwarf pick up or what 100 archery does. Tooltip and ingame help is way too casual. - Balance issue (archery is the only way to go, melee makes health management more intense, while magic is simply not reliable), swarms of enemies required escaping until tesla tech, then BAM, they are not a problem anymore at all suddenly and further gameplay become less intense (and more boring).  Pros: - It's simply beauteful game with variaty of activities. - Company, while consists from only 4 maps is in fact quite a long journey: every map is different, brings something new and each map took for me 30+ hours (!) to finish.

This game is extremely addictive and very good.   It's a sandbox game similar to Terraria, yet it certainly remains distinct.   The game looks very beautiful. And, it's fun. It's fun to control all of these dwarves, but it can be like trying to herd cats at times. You have the option of controlling one dwarf, while ordering the others about, or you can take an overview of the map, and tell them all what to do. The AI is pretty good, and they usually do a great job going where you tell them to, and taking the best routes. They're very responsive too.   There are a ton of things to craft and learn how to build, along with a ton of materials to discover. The enemies can be very dangerous at times ( e.g. during waves).   The controls are not very intuitive at first, but once you catch on it's pretty easy.

Take the simulation, community management, and crafting aspects of games like Towns, Space Base DF9, and Gnomoria and the 2d graphics of terraria and wrap it in a very well designed interface and you have Craft the World. I have very few complaints about this game but here they are: - Gnomes sometimes fall through the floor if you are changing the shape of a wall piece they are standing on and they are unable to path their way out ofthe hole, you have to take control of that dwarfand jump out, quickly fix the hole and hope that another dwarf doesnt find his way in there while you are switching the block (pausing works but takes just as long to pause the game as it does to fix the hole) - Playing without the tech tree can leave you without some of the basic crafted materials until late in the game. I didnt get the recipe for clay untill after my dwarfs were decked out in silver armor and weapons. - There does not seem to be enough ore to go around in the small worlds, I found myself mining huge swaths of the underground to find a few pieces of iron or silver to finish an item  On the plus side, this game was worth every cent og the $18.99 I paid for it. Craft the world fits every expectation I have for a crafting/simulation game and it stands strong where others have fallen short.  - The game play is easy to learn and the in game tutorials hold your hand at the begining but then let you run free when you are ready  - The Gnomes do a great job of collecting every single piece of material left behind, sometimes it takes a while if you have dug a huge hole, cut down a bunch of trees, and purchased some stuff from the shop. The dwarf's carrying capacity is very limited and carrying 3 leaves is the same to them as carrying 3 chunks of stone but they get the job done eventually. Sometimes you just have to sit back and watch them scurry around or use one of the magic spells to help them along. The portal and imp spells work great for gathering large amounts of material left in one place.

Just finished the first world, so I feel a review is now fair to write. Love this game! You take charge of a growing squad of dwarves, and give them tasks as needed, in order to make the world a nice place for a clan of dwarves to settle. But enemies will also come for your kingdom, so take the time to prepare. You can either just give orders and sit back, or you can get your own hands dirty by taking control of any individual dwarf for certain tasks.  The game has a lot of replay value. The first campaign, at a fairly normal pace but trying to explore most of the world, took about 25 to 30 hours. Graphics are simple and cutesy, but still quite pretty and functional for what the game is trying to do. The crafting tree is robust, with a lot of functional and cosmetic items. Though, even cosmetic items are functional in a way, given how the dwarves' resting mechanic works.  The only real drawback to this game comes when you gather quite the party of dwarves (over 10). Then, the dwarven AI individually tends to compete, and they start to derp in frustrating ways. You'll see 2 or 3 dwarves competing for a single task and getting waylaid on the other side of portals if you don't micromanage certain tasks. Too, sometimes dwarves will fail their tasks for no apparent reason, or plain not recognize their task. Fortunately, you can (usually) clear this problem by taking control of a dwarf and/or immediately releasing him.   All in all, the game is fully worth the $20 it was at regular price. If you catch it on a Steam sale, you'll do even better. For lovers of simpler real-time strategy, with mining/crafting elements, building, and some battling!

Rant alert: This is one of my favorite games I have bought recently. Hopefully, my 90+ hours of play time will show that! I really enjoy commanding dwarves to carve out through the depths of the underground. After I first bought the game, my first reactions were 'This looks so very nice!', 'Wait... There are only    three    worlds?' and 'Holy crap this tech tree!' After my first 5+ hours I started to understand the games mechanics. Really easy to download and play, plus there is a tutorial, that is skippable when you start a new world. Now the problems I have with the game. Right around the middle of the tech tree, I find myself having to grind along. Most of that is because of a need for wool. The developers remedied this by adding traps and farms to maintain sheep. Unfortunately, both the farm fences and the trap require rope, which is made with wool, to make. Also, the AI for the dwarves still needs a little work. Often they will not pick up the resources I need and instead gather around tables for chats. That being said, the AI is not bad by any means. Recently there was an update that did help fix this. I have had a problems with occasional minor lag spikes and my saves corrupting if my computer bluescreens, which is not the developers fault. The fault lies with GeForce producing terrible cards ( and Nvidia producing updated ♥♥♥♥ drivers for older cards. Definitely worth $20. I would buy it again at that price, and an even better value if bought cheaper.   Pros: -The games art style -Large tech tree -Large maps -Personally control one dwarf at a time -Wide spectrum of enemies  Cons: -Grind, grind, grind -minor lag spikes  Bottom line: I would definitely buy this again and I would completely recommend this game for any of my friends.

I reccomend this game but only in some circumstances.  It's a fine game, its well made, the art is nice, graphics are vibrant and the gameplay and crafting systems are pretty in depth. The crafting system is especially well made and is probably the highlight. I've seen some people say its hard to control the Dwarfs and it is and isn't at the same time. Early game its easy to get your dwarfs moving in one direction. Late game once you get vast chasms of mines and tunnels you'll be tearing your hair out when goblins suddenly spawn next to your house while all your dwarfs but 2 or 3 are away in the tunnels. There are some useful presets you can give to your dwarfs to perform certain jobs, the lite RPG elements are neat and give serious benefits to highly leveld dwarfs for their jobs but it becomes damn near impossible to keep track of everything and keep all your dwarfs on the same page after your population hits 20 or 30.   The crafting is neat. You start you gathering resources and clearing tunnels and land. You develop a nice plot to place a house on and keep your dwarfs slept and fed and then you go from there progressively upgrading and improving your tools, armor, weapons and workbenches. The crafting system has a fairly deep system but it still didn't seem deep enough to keep me interested late game. After so long it became more of a stalemate and i couldn't keep up nor could i dig far enough and build enough ladders to get to the best ores. At this point i lost interest since i was more or less in a slogging grind and was making little to no progress. To some that may be part of the fun, and it is for me usually, but the crafting system wasn't deep enough to keep me grinding. Since crafting is one of the main, if not the main, selling points of this game that can be a hit or miss depending on who you are or what you like. I'd recommend it to people who can get this game on the cheap and enjoy cartoony games with lots of charm and a neat little twist on the craft/survive genre.   Its got a bit of Minecraft, Terraria and a bit of RTS-RPG like Warcraft 3. It has good charm from your dwarfs and some of the enemies you battle. It has vibrant colors with clean, well made graphics that fit the atmosphere and gameplay perfectly. And finally the sound design and quality are pretty top notch for an indie game or Mobile port (not sure if this is a mobile port but it seems like one).   Pros  -Vibrant Colors and Graphics. Very clean and pretty. -Nice sounds and music. Helps keep the charm of the game up during play. -Charm. This game has a good amount of charm, atleast to me. -RPG elements. It has several layers and types of RPG elements -Crafting system. Its fairly easy to understand, a bit convoluted but has decent depth. -RTS elements with individual characters having their own equipment slots. -Many different jobs and noticable changes to productivity from job skills leveling up.  Cons -Turns into a grind late game. -Crafting system wasn't deep enough to keep me interested late game or long term. -Some enemies seem very annoying, the goblins especially. -The game is good in many different facets but doesn't really excell at any one in specific. -Somewhat convoluted design to mages and some crafting recipes. -A slight learning curve, especially for those new to the genre. -Some of the items and furniture seem useless and arbitrary.  Thats about it. Its good little game. I feel it was worth the price. I think i payed $7.50 or $10 for it and i got a nice, enjoyable 10 hours out of it. I'll probably come back a few months down the line to give it another play through because the game does have a lot of charm to me despite its flaws. Its a, for the most part, technically solid game that was better than i'd expected. I think it deserves a buy if you're into Terraria/Starcraft, Minecraft and other games of that ilk. I wouldn't reccomend it on its RPG-RTS elements alone but they blend together well with the survival/craft elements to make a rather enjoyable and worthwhile game, even if its worth wasn't that long for this one guy.

After 30 hours of gameplay on a larger size map the game becomes a bit boring. Dwarves move slowly, mana regenerates slowly (so you cannot be using portal spell too often), maximum speed of the game is x2 (I play on max speed 95% of time). There are a few minor bugs, but they don't prevent from enjoying the game - sometimes item cannot be removed from a quick access bar or dwarves behave as if their IQ dropped to one digit number. Quick access bar at the beginning seems quite small but you get used to it (and there is another one available by pressing ctrl). There is no loading a save game - game autosaves, so when you exit you come back to what you built, hence it is not possible to undo mistakes (other than to copy save files to another directory and then bring them back).  I don't remember a game released in the past few years which would be so cheap and which I would play so long - this game is definitely worth this £14.00.  I am looking forward to see some other means of transport like horses, increased maximum game speed to x5 or x10 and normal game save/load system.

tl;dr - Craft the World is a well-put-together game with lots to do and many ways to play. You may get very frustrated with it, though, depending on your preferred style of play.    I'm not fond of playing castle defense games, probably because I get easily flustered under time pressure. When I first tried the campaign in Craft the World, I nearly deleted it in frustration: the waves of enemies never gave me enough time to learn how to play the game.   Luckily, you can control the difficulty (and number of waves) in a sandbox game. So for those who are more casual players, who like to dig deep into how a game works, or who aren't used to castle defense games, Craft the World still has lots of fun to offer.   The developers have put a lot of effort into the game: the graphics, sound, and music are polished, the monsters are interesting and varied, the items/recipes are extensive (and frequently even logical), and they've clearly devoted a lot of time to the dwarf AI.   The dwarf AI quality is mixed: On the one hand, the dwarves have some stupid behaviors, and don't handle large amounts of commands well. On the other hand, when I took the time to learn the ins and outs of how they act, I found their behavior predictable, and could usually find a game mechanic that would allow me to control the behaviors I didn't want.

So I picked this game up in the Steam Summer Sale a week-ish ago and I've played almost a full day of it as I'm writing this review. This game is really addicting if you ever enjoyed things like Dwarf Fortress, or other village builder games such as Rim World, the controls are pretty hands off for most tasks, click a block and a dwarf will wander over and mine it, click an enemy and your colony will rush over and bash, slash, hack, and shoot it until it dies or they get too low on health and have to run away. If you want a ton of fine tuned controls and exceptional AI then this is not the game for you, however.  For the full run down here we go Pros   Dwarves   Decent structure building   AI is usually smart enough to have your dwarves get out of fatal situations   Once you craft an item once you can quick craft it by just clicking at the bottom of the interface   The Totem and dwarves finally tell you how in the heck to make a structure be valid housing for dwarves as of the update this morning (I had a lot of issues my first game because dwarves refuse to sleep in beds and heal if the structure isn't complete)   Enemy variety is surprisingly good, compared to something like Minecraft where you have 5 passive creatures, and maybe 7 hostile ones that aren't bosses and the number of enemy types in this game are astounding, I already have 40 pages in my bestiary and I've only played the first level and run through Biomes   Multiplayer can be great fun, but even the co-op mode isn't really working in tandem most of the time  Cons   Dwarves are notoriously bad swimmers, this can lead to them drowning at random if it rains for too long in the game, shut your doors during storms or you may have a bad time   The actual tutorial in the game doesn't tell you much at all beyond basic controls and how to access menus, with a brief dip into crafting, I've played almost an entire 24 hours and I still can't figure out how to make a farmhouse actually do anything and planting crops is a task you can get within the first hour of playing   Speaking of tasks, it tells you almost nothing about how to complete them most of the time, it gives you a general idea of what you need to do and no actual steps with a few of them being exceptions outside of the ones tied to the tech tree   Dwarves are ocassionally dumber than a box of rocks, trapping themselves on ladders, refusing to go through doors, and sometimes being fatally stupid and standing completely still while being shot with arrows and magic and they don't even have the will to die fighting and at least shoot back   Fall damage is very unforgiving and with early tech levels nearly impossible to prevent as the early bridge that you get access to they can still fall off of, this has caused a handful of deaths so far by just watching dwarf after dwarf try to walk across the flat bridge and plummet to their deaths... I don't even have alcohol for them yet, come on game   Multiplayer just feels like a resource grab*   Dwarves dying in the multiplayer due to a poor generation causes them to still be dead in your singleplayer world, and they cannot take any gear whatsoever with them to the multiplayer session, so sometimes you just get all your dwarves rolled because you get a really low resource start and they get out-geared by the enemies and your high level dwarves are sometimes just gone, nothing you can say or do about it without being really far into the tech tree   The DLC that just came out, Sisters in Arms, is a ton of Quality of Life changes, and giving you dwarves that have a bit less HP, but a lot more speed, then it adds in a few new items, namely shields   A player with the DLC and a player without the DLC seem to have issues with multiplayer as since this morning any time I've spent in multiplayer if the other person has had female dwarves the game inevitably loses connection within a couple minutes   The inventory can sometimes become really clogged since (as far as I know) you can't sell or trash unwanted items, this has lead me to have a stockpile of 12 wooden clubs laying around 'just in case' while my dwarves are armed and armored to the teeth in silver and gold gear  *This is getting rather long now, but this section is going to be devoted entirely to the multiplayer portion of the game, so if you don't care about that then skip this and read the last words on the game.  The multiplayer game mode is not at all what I was expecting from a survival/town builder style game, in fact large portions of it don't make any sense at all. Your two modes are PvP and Co-operative, only support for two players regardless of mode, the goal of PvP is kill the other person's dwarves, the goal of Co-operative is... well I'd love to tell you, but it fluctuates based on the biome and sometimes seems like it has no real goal, it just ends when it feels like it.   In the cons earlier one of them was that multiplayer feels like a resource grab and well, at least with the co-operative mode that's all it is. You go to a world where all of the techs are unlocked, resources are all over the place, and the end goal in theory is to kill a big bad boss somewhere deep underground. I say in theory because you never actually have to kill the thing in the standard biome, you can just sneak into its lair and break the loot chest and without another word the session just ends, it totals up the score of the players and you go back to your world. tl;dr - Craft the World is a well-put-together game with lots to do and many ways to play. You may get very frustrated with it, though, depending on your preferred style of play.    I'm not fond of playing castle defense games, probably because I get easily flustered under time pressure. When I first tried the campaign in Craft the World, I nearly deleted it in frustration: the waves of enemies never gave me enough time to learn how to play the game.   Luckily, you can control the difficulty (and number of waves) in a sandbox game. So for those who are more casual players, who like to dig deep into how a game works, or who aren't used to castle defense games, Craft the World still has lots of fun to offer.   The developers have put a lot of effort into the game: the graphics, sound, and music are polished, the monsters are interesting and varied, the items/recipes are extensive (and frequently even logical), and they've clearly devoted a lot of time to the dwarf AI.   The dwarf AI quality is mixed: On the one hand, the dwarves have some stupid behaviors, and don't handle large amounts of commands well. On the other hand, when I took the time to learn the ins and outs of how they act, I found their behavior predictable, and could usually find a game mechanic that would allow me to control the behaviors I didn't want.

I rarely had to budget my resources, which actually detracted from the game. In short, the game needs balancing.  With tha being said, I beat all four levels of the game and really enjoyed myself right up to the end. I found the graphics enjoyable as well as the crafting system--though it is very linear. Overall, I recommend it for the price.

4/5 Great game, very addicting. I've only made 2 worlds and have spent 40 hours on one and 20 on the second. The game itself feels looks alot like Terraria but plays alot differently. The best way I would describe it is that Terraria is an RPG where you level up and improve your character as you explore, mine, gather and build, whereas this game is more like an RTS where you control multiple dwarves to mine, gather and build. As you level up in Craft the World you get an additional dwarf that can carry out commands, as well as use equipment to increase his armor, damage, gathering speed and some other abilities as well. The more dwarves you have the faster you will be able to build, mine, gather and defend your base. Base defense is important as every 45 minutes monster portals will spawn somewhere outside and nearby your home which will pour monsters into the world for the remainder of the night (the portal always opens at the beginning of a night) to cause havoc for your dwarves and the fortress you're building for them. The game also offers many different monsters which you'll find in the world, from Goblins to Guardians, that will make you scour your world and fill it with an intricate series of tunnels and mineshafts.  I would like to share some suggestions to improve this game to make it a 5/5: -Add a way to break down items for materials, more crafting recipes that use them, or a way to delete items; inventory in the late game is cluttered with early items you have no use for -Add improved bow towers that use second and third level bows, and have stone and iron bodies that also improve their durability -Add more shops to the worlds which may be harder to find but sell items like equipment, and maybe some unique items that can't be crafted.  -Add a third level portal as a final-tier tech that you allows you to build multiple portals that your dwarves can teleport between -Some way for dwarves to fly short distances, perhaps a helicopter backpack as a late game tech, I think that would look awesome :P

This game has me quite torn. It has so much potential to be a really awesome game but just a few things hold it back, I think.  I really like the base mechanics of the game. This can lead to annoyance as things can become high priority to you and your people continue to do the other 'housekeeping' tasks you've set. I could be wrong, but as far as I know, there's no way to increase priority of tasks. That's definitely a problem.  The other thing is that even on the 'fastest' setting, the game gets boring waiting for your dwarves to complete their tasks (even if they immediately jump on them), especially early on when you only have 1-2 dwarves and basic equipment. I know it's kind of supposed to feel like that early on, but this is too much. I'm just staring at the screen waiting far too often.  Also, there is a time box constantly counting down. Every 30 or so minutes (15 I think on the fastest setting), a large group of mobs attack your people. They aren't generally too difficult to defeat, but it does absolutely require your attention. I like the feature, but not ALL the time. This is a crafting game, primarily, and the demographic that likes crafting and building usually doesn't like constant distractions. We want to build our giant god damn usless-but-purty constructions and landscapes.  Lastly, the non-sandbox modes are brutal. Even if you have the materials to craft something, you can't craft it until you reach enough experience in the prerequisit tech tree research. I find myself crafting 14 'dyes' or 8 diving helmets or whatnot just to get enough experience in that tech to be able to craft further. It's infuriating at times. The crafting isn't all that streamlined either. Everytime you craft something new you must drag each ingredient from your inventory to its proper place. That would be forgivable IF you weren't required to craft nearly 100% of what's possible to craft to get to the end of the tech tree. One or the other. Absolutely not both.   Like I said, this game has so much potential, and as it is, it was still fairly fun for me for at least the first time through. However, now when I play I just end up frustrated every time. It's like the designers are too concerned with 'what makes sense?' and not enough with 'what is fun?'. Streamline menus, find a new crafting/tech system, speed the game up, realtime 'increase priority of task', and don't have the mob attack timer on constantly. Maybe a mob attacks only when you steal a rune or something underground so you can choose the time.  It's mostly a solid game, and I'm sure some people will get a lot of enjoyment out of it. Make note of the date of this writing - perhaps they will update it and fix some issues. I want so badly to like it but sadly it isn't there yet.

While the concept of this game is cool, the execution is terrible. For a fortress management game, Craft the World is severely lacking in tools that enable the player to manage their little dwarf colony.  Basically the way dwarves are managed is that you assign tasks by clicking on objects/tiles to harvest or creatures to kill, assigning things to be crafted, and for objects to be placed. Along with these tasks, there is also the generic task of picking up objects that are dropped when resources are harvested. The dwarves themselves decided which of the above tasks they will do, and in what order. From what I've seen, unless one of their skills correlates to one of the jobs (more on that later), they will simply do whatever task is quickest to complete. The only exception to this is when selecting an enemy to attack. In this pretty much all dwarves will drop what they are doing to attack the enemy.  There is no way for the player to prioritize tasks or to restrict dwarves to only do certain tasks. This means that trying to multitask is pretty much impossible as dwarves focus on tasks closest to the stockpile because they are the quickest to complete, ignoring tasks further away even if the further ones are more important. As a result things take forever to complete. This is made even worse when you take the pathfinding into account, expecially when it comes to gathering resources. When a dwarf is gathering resources it tries to fill its inventory before dropping things off at the stockpile. This means that if its inventory space is 3, and it is holding 2 objects while next to the stockpile and there is group resource across the map, the dwarf will walk all the way over to the distant pile, pick up one object, then walk all the way back to the stockpile to drop the objects off when clearly it'd be more efficient to drop off what it has, then go pickup 3 objects from the distant pile.  The only real management tools the player has is a portal and the mostly worthless skills mechanic. The portal spell opens a temporary shortcut between a tile on the map and a the stockpile. These portals are taken into account when calculating the speed at which a task can be completed, artficially giving distant tasks a higher 'priority' in the dwarves todo list. However, in order to keep the piority of distant tasks high the player must constantly open up new portals near distant tasks as the tasks closest to the old portal gets completed, as the further a task is from a portal, the lower its priority is.  Along with the portals, each can also have up to 3 skills that can influence which types of jobs it takes. For example, a dwarf with the mining skill will try to mine blocks before it tries to cut down trees, even if the trees are a quicker task to complete. Unfortunately this mechanic is almost completely worthless as each dwarf only starts with one skill, and what that skill they start with is competely worthless. This means that you'll most likely start with a bunch of dwarves that are skilled in worthless stuff like swimming and milling, when you really need things like mining, logging, carpentry and smithing at the start of the game. Furthermore, the only way to get new skills for a dwarf is by applying skill books to a dwarf. These books are rare drops that you get sometimes after harvesting a resource. Unfortunately what skills these books teach are also completely random, meaning that you might go an hour before a book drops with a skill that you need.  Overall the gameplay is excrutatingly slow and tedious. As far as I can tell the 'Campaign' of the game is just a sequence of randomly generating maps where in each one you have to build a portal in order to reach the next map. The portal pieces are hidden in secret rooms underground that you have to find. As levels progress the maps slowly get bigger and the difficulty gets higher. There are no special scenarios or win conditions for any of the maps as far as I can tell, making the Campaign feel extremely boring and repetitive after the first level.  In short, do not buy this game.
